past.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: done, used, or experienced before now
past.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Judging by her past performance, Jane should do very well.
From past experience she knew that it was no use arguing with him.
Study some past exam papers to get an idea of the questions.
past.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: used to refer to a period up until now
past.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: the events of the past year
During the past two weeks, 12 people have died of the disease.
She has been feeling tired for the past few days.
past.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: finished or having come to an end
past.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Winter is past and spring has come at last.
a tradition rooted in times long past
past.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: having held a particular position in the past or achieved a particular honour in the past
past.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: a celebration for past and present employees of the newspaper
Bruce Jenner, a past Olympic champion
a past president of the golf club
past.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I should be finished by half past  (=30 minutes after the hour).
It was past midnight when the party ended.
Come on Annie, it’s long past your bedtime.
past.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The hospital’s just up this road, about a mile past the school.
There are parking spaces over there, just past (=a little further than) the garage.
past.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: up to and beyond a person or place, without stopping
past.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: She waved as she drove past.
Will you be going past my house on your way home?
Monica hurried straight past me and down the steps.
past.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: if a period of time goes past, it passes
past.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Weeks went past without any news.
The hours seemed to fly past.
past.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: beyond or no longer at a particular point or stage
past.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: The roses were already past their best.
Reid never really got past the stage of copying other artists.
a pot of yoghurt well past its sell-by date
an Italian singer who was then past her prime  (=no longer strong and active)
I’m past caring about my appearance  (=I do not care about it anymore).
past.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the past life or existence of someone or something
past.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: At some time in its past the church was rebuilt.
The woman who ran the bar had a very shady past (=events in her past which might be considered bad).
past.translation[2].note_box[0].sections: The optimistic economic climate of the recent past has gone.
Rivers of molten lava clearly flowed here in the distant past.
In order to understand the present, we must look at the immediate past.
Forget the past and focus on the future.
You’ve got to stop living in the past.
be/become a thing of the past
We hope that smoking will become a thing of the past.
These policies are a break with the past.
in the dim and distant past
I think she sang Ireland's entry in the Eurovision Song Contest sometime in the dim and distant past.
past.translation[2].note_box[1].sections: at a time before now, especially a long time ago
In the past, most children didn’t go to school at all.
We had a big argument, but it’s all in the past now.
in those days/in the old days
a long time ago in your life, or in your parents’ or grandparents’ lives, when things were different
£5 was a lot of money in those days.
In the old days, only very rich people had cars.
used for saying that something was true in the past, but is not now
At one time there were six schools in the village.
I would have agreed with you at one time.
used when you are talking about a time in the past, especially one that you remember as being very good
I loved Blondie back in the day.
Back in the day, everyone would meet at the boys’ club.
